importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the timeline of events surrounding the air strike and the subsequent diplomatic and sporting repercussions.
The 48-hour truce between Afghanistan and Pakistan expired at 13:00 GMT on October 19, 2025, prompting renewed tensions and leading to the extension of the truce for peace negotiations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The temporary truce between Afghanistan and Pakistan between October 18 and 19, 2025, ended just before the incident, setting the stage for increased violence and diplomatic action.

keyTakeAways: Afghanistan withdrew from an upcoming tri-nation T20 cricket series following the killing of three local players in an air strike it blamed on Pakistan.
The strike occurred in the Urgon district of Paktika province, where the players were dining after a match, and resulted in eight fatalities, including civilians.
Pakistan denied targeting civilians, claiming the strike targeted militants and killed at least 70 combatants, rejecting accusations as false and politically motivated.
The International Cricket Council (ICC) expressed deep sorrow and condemned the violence, showing solidarity with the Afghanistan Cricket Board.
Afghan national team captain Rashid Khan and other players publicly expressed grief and condemned the attack as a heinous crime.
A 48-hour truce between Afghanistan and Pakistan had expired, leading to renewed hostilities and border clashes, prompting a new round of peace talks in Doha, Qatar.
The Taliban government stated it would participate in the peace talks despite criticizing Pakistan’s actions as aggressive and aimed at prolonging conflict.
Former Afghan President Hamid Karzai urged Pakistan to reconsider its policies and pursue civil and friendly relations.
Zimbabwe has replaced Afghanistan in the T20 series due to the withdrawal.
Pakistan's Defence Minister Khawaja Asif will lead the delegation to the Doha peace talks, which focus on ending cross-border terrorism and restoring stability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Afghanistan has withdrawn from an upcoming tri-nation T20 cricket series following the killing of three local cricketers in an air strike it blames on Pakistan. The strike occurred in the Urgon district of Paktika province, where the players were dining after a match, resulting in eight deaths, including civilians. Pakistan denies targeting civilians, claiming the strike killed Afghan militants, and rejects accusations of bias from the ICC, which expressed deep sorrow and condemned the violence. The incident occurred just after a temporary truce between the two nations expired, reigniting border clashes. In response, peace talks have been resumed in Doha, Qatar, with both nations participating despite tensions. The Afghan cricket board and national players, including Rashid Khan and Fazalhaq Farooqi, have publicly mourned the victims, emphasizing the loss to Afghan youth and sports. Zimbabwe has stepped in to replace Afghanistan in the series.
title: Afghanistan pulls out of cricket series after it says Pakistan air strike killed local players
